articles.title: What’s New: Moraware Recap Fall 2024
articles.content: What’s New: Moraware Recap Fall 2024 TRANSCRIPT: Hi, I'm Chelsea. Wondering what we've been doing behind the screen? Our development team is consistently working to update Moraware Systemize, Inventory, and CounterGo to provide you with the best experience for managing your business. From keeping your system secure, managing larger jobs, and making it easier to use Moraware products, here's a quick recap of just a few of the most recent feature updates. Let's start with an important topic, no matter what Moraware product you use. We've enhanced the security of your database and information with Two Factor Authentication at login. Enabling the feature is not required, but highly recommended since it's the best way to prevent unauthorized access to your account. Systemize Phases are a helpful way to break up larger Jobs and schedule smaller blocks of work separately. When viewing Job Details, the new Phase Filter option allows for selecting and viewing all Activities, Forms, Orders, and uploaded Files related to the Phase or Phases selected. This means less scrolling and easier visibility of only the information you need. For Systemize users who also use Moraware Inventory, recent enhancements allow for Serial Numbers to be searched to find specific slabs easier. Three new features in CounterGo make it easier to quote larger Jobs. Line item only Quotes Without Drawings can now be created. Quotes Without Drawings are helpful to quickly total square footage, especially when a drawing and measurements have already been provided. Square feet, or measurements, along with Curves, Bump outs, Splash, Edge, Sinks, and Cutouts can all quickly be added without creating a Drawing. CounterGo now has the option to create one drawing and then multiply the Quantities of the area in Step 6, making it faster to create multi-unit Quotes that use the same countertop layouts. Page Breaks can now be added to the Drawing Area when printing Quotes, making it easier to read larger or more complex layouts. This feature works best when printed or emailed with a Quote & Order form that has the Drawing Area set to the full width, like the built-in Quote With Large Drawing Form. Additional Countergo improvements were released to make Quoting and Drawing easier and more intuitive. Starting with Pan and Zoom when drawing, keyboard arrow shortcuts have been added when using the Pan feature. Use the Shift key and the mouse to Pan without selecting it from the side menu. Zoom now anchors to the center of the drawing space and works using a magic mouse, mouse with a scroll wheel, two finger touch on a trackpad, or keyboard plus and minus shortcuts. Waterfall and Miters can now be applied to non standard edges.Those that are segmented have bump outs or bump ins, notched or clipped corners. As with standard waterfalls and miters, the amount of Material required, as well as a charge for the two cuts between the pieces, is automatically calculated. The last CounterGo feature to highlight is the ability to add the Total Price as a Display Column in Quote Views. We're pleased to have added these new product features and updates to provide you with an improved Moraware experience. If you have any questions, reach out to our friendly Moraware Support Team at support@moraware.com.Thanks for stopping by!

articles.title: Rotate Text In CounterGo Drawings
articles.content: Rotate Text In CounterGo Drawings Have you added text to your Drawing and want to change the direction of the text block? When text blocks are added to a drawing in Steps 1-4, they can be rotated by clicking on the text in Drawing Area. This feature applies only to text that you manually add to a Drawing. Be sure you are in a Drawing Step between Steps 1-4. Click on the text you have added to the canvas. Rotate the text to the left or right by selecting from the menu. Continue to click on Rotate Text Left or Rotate Text Right until the text block is in desired orientation. Once rotated, click, hold, and drag text to a new location in the drawing if needed.

articles.title: Create Mitered Edges With Mitered Cuts
articles.content: Create Mitered Edges With Mitered Cuts Do you need to create a Mitered Edge with Mitered Cuts? Mitered Edges with Cuts can be created in just a few clicks in Step 3 when drawing a Quote. The feature will create the Material pieces and their associated cuts, no need to draw additional pieces. Mitered Edge Material pricing is calculated based on the price of the Material selected in Step 5. Material pieces will be created and shown in Area & Slab Layout in Step 5. Prices for Mitered Cuts can be added to the Price List, or manually entered in Step 6. The total Linear Feet of the Mitered Cuts in Step 6 includes the edge between adjacent Mitered Cut and Material. When a CounterGo Order is converted to a Systemize Job, the imported Order Information includes the total Material needed for the countertop, and the Mitered Cuts total. Draw a countertop in Step 1. Click on the edge that will have the Mitered Edge > select Mitered Edge > enter the Height. Go to Step 5 > Select a Product, Color, and Edge. Go to Step 6 > manually enter/edit prices for Mitered Cuts if not entered in the Price List.

articles.title: Set Centerline Dimension For Sinks Or Cooktops
articles.content: Set Centerline Dimension For Sinks Or Cooktops Set the centerline for your sinks or cooktops during Step 4. Go to Step 4 on your quote and click on the drawing for your sink, sink cutout, or cooktop cutout and select Properties. From the Show Centerline drop-down, select Right or Left to specify which side you want the centerline measured from. Save. You can drag and drop to adjust the measurement or click on the measure and enter a value.

articles.title: Draw Non-Standard Backsplash Or Waterfall Edge
articles.content: Draw Non-Standard Backsplash Or Waterfall Edge Do you need to see Splash or Edge pieces in the Drawing? Instead of adding a standard Splash or Edge in Step 3, draw the piece in Step 1. Pieces with a minimum width of 1 inch can be drawn in CounterGo. Scenarios that call for drawing Splash or Edge manually instead of the built-in options in Step 3 include: Using a different Material for the Splash than the countertop Material. Applying a different Edge Type to the Splash than the countertop Edge. Gap/split in Splash for a window or range hood. Need to put a Splash on a Bump-out. Draw the countertops then draw the Splash or Edge as a separate piece. Label each piece using the Text button. For waterfall edges, go to Step 3 and select Additional Finished Edge to the will have miter seam. Select the Edge Type in Step 5.

articles.title: Add A Slab Image
articles.content: Add A Slab Image Ready to add images to your countertop drawings? Adding a Slab Image allows your customer to see an example of how the counter could look with a selected Product. You can upload new images to a Quote or Order, or search for an image previously uploaded. BEFORE YOU BEGIN: Save images of slabs on your computer or in a cloud storage location of your choice. We recommend naming images according to what they are, to make it easier to search later on. Save images as BMP, GIF, JPEG, or PNG formats. The limit on the size of the file to be uploaded is 30 MB. ADD A NEW IMAGE In Step 5 click the green Area Slabs & Layout bar and check Show Layout if no layout is visible. Click the slab dimensions, then Select Image > Add Image File. Click Choose File to Upload and browse to select an image from your computer or cloud. Adjust the boundary of the shaded rectangle to select the usable area by clicking, holding and dragging any corner.To move the shaded rectangle, click and hold inside the rectangle to reposition it. SEARCH FOR A PREVIOUSLY USED IMAGE In Step 5 click the green Area Slabs & Layout bar and check the Show Layout box. Click the slab dimensions then Select Image. Enter the name of the image into search box and click Search icon. Choose file from search results. Adjust the red boundary box if needed.

articles.title: Draw Multiple Edges On One Countertop
articles.content: Draw Multiple Edges On One Countertop If you are new to applying Multiple Edges in your Quotes, start with the related article Understanding Multiple Edges before proceeding. On Step 3, select an edge and choose Additional Finished Edge. On Step 5, select your first Edge and then below it click +Edge. Select your second Finished Edge, but notice that it is marked "Unused" next to the Edge 2. Click on the thumbnail drawing of your countertop on the left, and choose the Edge you want for your other Finished Edge 2. Both Edges indicate they are being used on a counter.

articles.title: Draw Full Radius Edge
articles.content: Draw Full Radius Edge You can create a full radius edge on Step 2 using either the Full Radius option or by adding a Bump-Out Arc. If you chose Full Radius, no material will be added to the length of the edge to create the depth of the arc. If you chose Bump-Out Arc, then CounterGo will add the depth of the arc to the length of the countertop. To create arc that adds material to length, select Add Bump-Out Arc. Enter the Depth and Width. To create arc that does NOT add material to length, select Full Radius.

articles.title: Outlet Cutout Count
articles.content: Outlet Cutout Count Need to add the number of outlet cutouts as a line item in your Quotes or Orders? CounterGo makes it easy to indicate how many outlet cutouts there will be in Step 4, listing that number in Step 6. The Outlet Cutout Count feature totals the number of cutouts only, it does not provide a cutout shape for placement on countertops or splashes. You can either enter the number of cutouts on each counter piece or enter the total number of cutouts for the entire Quote or Order on one piece. All the Outlet Cutout Counts will be totaled into one line item in Step 6. Go to Step 4 of a Quote or Order. Click inside any countertop. Select Outlet Cutout Count from the pop-up menu. Enter either the number of cutouts on that counter piece or the total number of cutouts for the Quote or Order. Go to Step 6 to see the Outlet Cutout Count listed as a line item.

articles.title: Make A Vertical Text Label
articles.content: Make A Vertical Text Label CounterGo does have a Text feature that allows for the entire text block to be rotated. If you need to have the text stacked vertically, manually add each letter using return or enter on your keyboard to place one letter per line. At any time in Steps 1 - 4, click on the Text button from the right side menu. Enter the text > Save. Click once on the text to reveal a menu > select to Rotate Left or Rotate Right. This rotates the entire label. MANUAL PROCESS: To stack the letters of the label one on top of another, enter one character per line and return after each letter. Click Save. Indenting each character in vertical orientation can create a sloping effect if manually entering text.

articles.title: Use Slab Layout
articles.content: Use Slab Layout Ready to take a look at how counter pieces might fit on a Slab? The Area Slab Layout in Step 5 lets you seam, rotate, and arrange counter top pieces on slabs. This is a powerful tool to estimate how many slabs are required. Remember that this is for estimating purposes only, not for cutting. Slab Layout is also where images are uploaded to place on Slabs. See related articles for more. In Step 5 Click > Area #1 Slabs & Layout. If you've selected a Color that is priced by Square Feet, check to Show Layout. Click, hold and drag to arrange countertops on the Slab(s). When all the pieces are green, there is no overlap, and all pieces are on the Slab(s). Click once on a counter top in the thumbnail image to highlight all the pieces from that top in the Slab Layout. Click and hold, without moving a piece, on any piece on the Slab to highlight which counter top it belongs to in the thumbnail, and all the associated pieces.

articles.title: Draw An Oval Or Circular Counter
articles.content: Draw An Oval Or Circular Counter Need to create an oval or circle-shaped surface in CounterGo? Begin with a rectangular or square top, then add a radius to each corner equivalent to 1/2 the side length. CounterGo is not capable of complex, non-symmetric shapes such as a trapezoid or true ovals/ellipses. In Step 1 draw a rectangle or square. To create a circle, draw a square with sides equal to the desired diameter of the circle. In Step 2, click on a corner of the surface and select Radius, entering a value half the length of a side. Repeat for each corner until an oval or circle is formed.

articles.title: Edit Edge Measurements
articles.content: Edit Edge Measurements Looking for a quick way to edit a single edge, or multiple edges, on a countertop? CounterGo lets you edit one Edge Length, or multiple ones in one place. Open the Drawing of any Quote or Order. Click on any Edge measurement while in Steps 1, 2 or 4. Edit the Edge Length. Click Save & Next to save the change and move to the next edge, the orange highlight indicates which edge is being modified. Click Save to save and exit.

articles.title: Draw A Curved Countertop
articles.content: Draw A Curved Countertop Need to create a curved bar top or overhang? Modify a rectangular piece to achieve a curved countertop. Draw a rectangle in Step 1. In Step 2 click the edge and choose Add Bump-Out Arc. Set the Depth and Width equal to the depth and width of the original rectangle. Click on the opposite edge and choose Add Bump-In Arc. Set the same Depth and Width, and now you have a curved top.

articles.title: Set Your Default Industry Terms
articles.content: Set Your Default Industry Terms By default, CounterGo contains terms that are generally appropriate for users in the United States. Some of the words used by default may be different from the names commonly used in the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada. There is a limited list of terms you have options to change, to customize what appears in Drawings, Quotes, and Orders. This list is found in Customize Text under Settings. Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Customize Text. Click the Text you want to change. Select an alternative from the Customized Text drop-down list.

articles.title: Add Or Remove Slabs
articles.content: Add Or Remove Slabs Need another slab in your layout? Have too many slabs? You can add or remove slabs in Step 5 of Quotes and Orders. Be sure you have clicked on Area Slab & Layout and Show Layout is checked. To add a slab, click on +Slab under the current slab. To remove a slab click on the dimensions to the right of the slab, then the Delete icon.

articles.title: Draw A U-Shaped Countertop
articles.content: Draw A U-Shaped Countertop Drawing a U-shaped countertop is easy with CounterGo - but it does take a few minutes of practice before you get a feel for how CounterGo draws. Begin in Step 1 by drawing a rectangle, but don't let go of your mouse. If you're working on a tablet or touchscreen device, don't lift your finger/stylus off the screen. As you pause, you'll see a 3-sided arrow appear. Once the 3-sided arrow appears, move your mouse (or finger/stylus) in the direction needed for your countertop. Pause again - without letting go of the mouse or lifting your finger/stylus - and draw the third side of your U-shape.

articles.title: Remove A Counter Area
articles.content: Remove A Counter Area If you've separated a Quote into two different areas but change your mind and want to remove an area, you must first reassign any countertops that are in the area you wish to remove. NOTE: If you're using the same material and color in each area but you want to layout the pieces together on the same slabs, the countertops have to be in the same Counter Area. Click on the countertop that you need to re-assign to a Counter Area and select "Make this countertop a member of...." When no countertops are assigned to a Counter Area, a Delete button will appear as an option. When all of the countertops are assigned to the same area, you can lay out the pieces on the same slabs.

articles.title: Add Or Edit A Sink Model With Cutout
articles.content: Add Or Edit A Sink Model With Cutout If you sell sinks, you can add the sink price and the cutout measurements at the same time when drawing your Quote. CounterGo will add a line item for both the sink and the cutout. When adding a Sink Model with a Cutout in Step 4, you will enter the price for the sink only, then in Step 6, you can enter the cost of the Sink Cutout. Add Sink Models to your Price List to speed things up. Click the countertop and select Add Sink Model. Enter the Name and Price of the sink only. Select Sink Type, Shape, Cutout Dimensions, Faucet Hole Count, and Centerline position of the cutout. Click and hold on the sink to adjust its position, or click the centerline measure to enter the distance from left or right. To edit the price or dimensions, click on the sink drawing and select Properties.

articles.title: Quote Complex Shapes
articles.content: Quote Complex Shapes Are you having trouble drawing a complex countertop? There are many interesting shapes that you can draw in CounterGo with several ways to draw those shapes. There may be shapes that you can't recreate exactly. Sometimes it's best to only draw bounding rectangles to approximate square footage. Other shapes can be broken into smaller shapes instead of being drawn as one continuous piece. This will allow you to arrive at a useful price for your Quote. In some cases, it's preferable to print the Quote without the Drawing. In general, non-standard shapes are approximated and their areas are totaled. CounterGo will always round up, so your Quote should not be short when it comes to estimated material, it should calculate slightly larger. Our friendly CounterGo experts are also happy to help think through the best approach for non-standard shapes. For help, send an email with a picture of what you are trying to recreate to support@moraware.com. Not every shape can be translated to CounterGo, but our team has seen many unique counters over the years and can offer suggestions when applicable.

articles.title: Rotate Sink Or Cutout On A Drawing
articles.content: Rotate Sink Or Cutout On A Drawing Do you need to change the orientation of a sink? Sinks and Cutouts can be rotated in Step 4. Go to Step 4 and click on a sink, sink cutout, or cooktop cutout drawing. Select Rotate Left or Rotate Right.

articles.title: Create Waterfalls With Mitered Cuts
articles.content: Create Waterfalls With Mitered Cuts Do you need to create a Waterfall with Mitered Cuts? Waterfalls and their associated Mitered Cuts can be created in just a few clicks in Step 3 when drawing a Quote. This feature will create the Waterfall pieces and their associated cuts, no need to draw additional pieces. Before using Waterfall Edges, enable the Waterfall Installation Charge in the Price List to have it automatically applied. It can be manually edited once enabled. If Waterfall Installation Charge is not enabled, it will not appear in Step 6. Waterfall Material pricing is calculated based on the price of the Material selected in Step 5. Material pieces will be created and shown in Area & Slab Layout in Step 5. Prices for Mitered Cuts and Waterfall Installation can be added to the Price List, or manually entered in Step 6. The total Linear Feet of the Mitered Cuts in Step 6 includes the edge between adjacent Mitered Cut and Waterfall. When a CounterGo Order is converted to a Systemize Job, the imported Order Information includes the total Material needed for the countertop, and the Mitered Cuts total. Draw a countertop in Step 1. Click on the edge that will have the Waterfall > select Waterfall Edge > enter the Height. Go to Step 5 > Select a Product, Color, and Edge. Go to Step 6 > manually enter/edit prices for Waterfall Installation Charge and Mitered Cuts if not entered in the Price List.

articles.title: Draw A Batwing Countertop
articles.content: Draw A Batwing Countertop Ready to create a batwing counter? Angled counter pieces are just a click away in CounterGo. Start with a standard U-shaped counter and modify the corner angles. Currently, custom counter angles are not supported. Experiment with the three preset angle options to see the various shapes that can be created. Draw a U-shaped countertop with 90° corners. Click inside a corner, on the 90° icon, and change the angle to one of the presets. Repeat the angle change action for the other corner to complete the batwing shape.

articles.title: Vertical & Horizontal Seams
articles.content: Vertical & Horizontal Seams Wondering if seam directions are fixed? Can horizontal and vertical seams be drawn? Seams can be displayed vertically or horizontally, but can not be mixed in the same countertop. By default, seams are perpendicular to the Default Counter Depth edge of a countertop, whether it is drawn left to right, right to left, top to bottom, or bottom to top. Seams are parallel to the Default Counter Depth edge regardless of the direction the top is drawn. Seam direction stays attached to the Default Counter Depth edge, even if the dimension is manually changed. To change the orientation of the seam, vertical or horizontal, keep in mind which edge began as a Default Counter Depth. Draw a counter, then switch the edge dimensions, and the seam will still run parallel to the original edges that were the default dimension.

articles.title: Use Bump-Out To Add Material For Radius Edge
articles.content: Use Bump-Out To Add Material For Radius Edge On Step 2 of a drawing, adding a Full Radius does NOT add material to the length. Instead, the radius edge will be drawn from the existing length. To add the material for the radius edge to the existing length, choose Add Bump-Out Arc on Step 2. After drawing your countertop, go to Step 2 and select the Edge that you want to be a full radius. Select Add Bump-Out Arc. Enter Depth (will be added to the existing length) and the set the Width equal to the full edge to create your full radius arc. Save.

articles.title: Change Individual Measurement Rounding
articles.content: Change Individual Measurement Rounding Need to change the measurement rounding on one particular Quote or Order but not all of them? The measurement Rounding can be changed on an individual Quote or Order while in Step 1. It will change for that Quote or Order only. Default Rounding for all Quotes and Orders will not change. In Step 1, click the Round to Nearest button from the right side menu. Select the level of precision from the available options.

articles.title: Non-Standard Waterfall/Mitered Edges Overview
articles.content: Non-Standard Waterfall/Mitered Edges Overview CounterGo has a built in Waterfall and Mitered Edge options in Step 3, that will calculate the amount of Material required, as well as a charge for the two cuts between the Material pieces. Waterfalls and Mitered Edges created in Step 3 will automatically create the mitered cut and the additional Material. If you need to create a Waterfall or Mitered Edge without using the standard feature, it can be done, but there are multiple steps involved. NOTE: The Edge Finish "miter" in Step 5 refers to the cut only, it does not include the Material for the extra pieces. When creating Waterfalls or Mitered Edges without using the standard Step 3 feature, whether the additional Edge is an apron all the way to the floor, or just a partial, it is important to draw the second piece that will miter to the first to account for the extra Material, before assigning any Edge Finishes. Creating non-standard (not using the Step 3 Waterfall/Mitered Edge feature) edges has four parts: draw the pieces indicate which edges will be mitered add a second edge finish type apply the finish to the countertop pieces. Example of the main counter and the edge Material for the miter in Step 1. Example of a Waterfall to the floor in Step 1.

articles.title: Remove Seams On Layout
articles.content: Remove Seams On Layout Need to remove a Seam from a counter? Seams can be edited in Step 5. Go to Step 5 and expand the Area #1 Slabs and Layout. Click the counter with the seam you would like to remove. Choose "Define Seams" and press the delete icon on the right. Press Save.

articles.title: Draw A Round Sink Or Sink Cutout
articles.content: Draw A Round Sink Or Sink Cutout Need to draw a round sink? You can represent a round sink by modifying the oval shape. You can create a round Sink Model, only the Cutout option, or both if needed. You can create a round sink while Quoting in Step 4, or better yet, add a Sink Model or Sink Cutout to your Price List to quickly select it in Step 4. CREATE A SINK CUTOUT OPTION Go to Price Lists > open the Price List to modify > click the Edit icon to the right of the Revision number to make changes. Scroll down to Sink Cutout Options. Click +Sink Cutout Option to add a cutout option. Select Oval for the shape and enter the dimensions (eg 12 x 12) then Save. CREATE A SINK MODEL Go to Price List > Retail open the Price List to modify > click the Edit icon to the right of the Revision number to make changes. Scroll down to Sink Model. Click +Sink Model to add a sink model. Enter Name and Price, select Oval for the shape and enter dimensions (eg 12 x 12) then Save.

articles.title: Segment An Edge For Multiple Splashes
articles.content: Segment An Edge For Multiple Splashes Sometimes a counter has different height Splashes along the same length of the piece, like a full-height splash behind a sink or cooktop. Segment the Edge in order to apply different Splashes to the same length of the counter piece. Go to Step 2 and click on the counter Edge you would like to modify. Add a Bump-In with the Depth as small as possible, ".1" inch. The program will round up, so you won't lose any square footage in your Quote. Go to Step 3, click the counter Edge you added the Bump-In to, and choose Segment This Edge. Click on the center section of the Edge and select Other Splash to add the full height Splash. Click on each adjacent portion of the Edge and add the appropriate Splash height.

articles.title: Draw Commonly Requested Shapes
articles.content: Draw Commonly Requested Shapes These linked articles are some of our most commonly requested shapes. If you need help with a shape not listed here, email support@moraware.com with a picture, and we'll get back to with suggestions. Pieces with a minimum width of 1 inch can be drawn in CounterGo. Draw A U-Shaped Countertop Draw A Batwing Countertop Draw A Curved Bar Top

articles.title: Understand Multiple Edges
articles.content: Understand Multiple Edges Understanding how to assign multiple edges to a countertop can be confusing at first. Multiple edges are created in Step 3 AND Step 5. In Step 3 you are telling the system if an edge has a finish style or does not, regardless of which edge style you will later choose. A finished edge is designated by the letter "F" and/or a number after it. An edge without a finished edge style is either Appliance or Unfinished. In Step 5 you tell the system which edge style to apply to each edge, regardless of the abbreviation in Step 3. Each time you click on an edge in Step 3, if that edge finish will be different from the other edges on that countertop, select Additional Finished Edge from the pop-up menu. In the example below, there are edges with and without a finish style on the L-shaped counter and each edge of the island has a different edge style. That totals of 6 possible edges for the entire Quote. Move to Step 5 and select to use 6 different edge styles by clicking Add Edge. Next, the edge styles will need to be assigned to each countertop. What you assign as "F1" on one counter is not automatically assigned to the same "F1" on another piece. Think of each countertop as unique. Click on the counter in the thumbnail and decide which edge style to assign to each different edge. In this example, the L-shaped counter is assigned first two edge styles on the list. Because there are 4 different edges for the island selected in Step 3 (F1-F4), there are 4 edge styles to assign in Step 5. You can use any of the 6 edge styles you previously added, each one is listed. Note: Once you have assigned each edge style to a Finished Edge, the list in Step 5 will show that each edge style has a counter(s) where it is used. if you see an edge style with "unused" next to the name, it has not been assigned. To assign them, just click on the thumbnail drawing and select that edge style from the list of options.

articles.title: Add Text On Drawing
articles.content: Add Text On Drawing A text annotation can be added to a drawing to label pieces, indicate the placement of appliances, etc. The text will print on the drawing, but not on the slab layout. Multiple labels can be added to a single drawing. To the right of the drawing, click the + Text button. Click on the drawing where you want the text to appear. Enter the text and change the Font or Color, if desired, and click Save. Once the text is on the drawing you can drag & drop it to move it (except on Step 4: Sink & Cooktop) To change the text or font size, click on the text label.

articles.title: Separate A Quote Into Areas
articles.content: Separate A Quote Into Areas Need to create more than one room in a single Quote? Need to know the square feet of each countertop drawn? Need to quote one Material on the kitchen perimeter and a different one on the island? Separate the Quote into different Areas in Step 5. Once you have assigned countertop pieces to different Areas, you can select different Materials, Colors, and Edges for those counters if needed. Any Splashes, Edges and Cutouts will be grouped with their respective countertop piece when subtotaling in Step 6. In Step 5, click +Counter Area. In the thumbnail drawing, click on the countertop you want to add to this Area, and select Make this counter a member of Area #2. Click the Edit icon to rename the Area. Select the Product, Color and Edge you want in each Area. In Step 6, the Pricing Details are separated by Area.

articles.title: Segment An Edge For Multiple Edge Finishes
articles.content: Segment An Edge For Multiple Edge Finishes Have a counter with multiple edge finishes on the same length of the piece? Segment the Edge then apply an Additional Finished Edge to apply different Edge Finishes to the same edge. Go to Step 2 and click on the counter Edge you would like to modify. Add a Bump-In with the Depth as small as possible, "0.1" inch. The program will round up, so you won't lose any square footage in your Quote. Go to Step 3. Click the counter Edge you added the Bump-In to, and choose Segment This Edge. Click the segmented portion of the Edge that will have a different finish and choose Additional Finished Edge. Go to Step 5 and click +Edge to add an additional Edge. Designate your Edges by clicking on the green counter in the thumbnail drawing to the left and assign the different Edge finishes.

articles.title: Add A Seam To A Countertop
articles.content: Add A Seam To A Countertop Ready to indicate where seams will be on a countertop? In Step 5 you can define where to place seams in your countertop. By default, seams are perpendicular to the Default Counter Depth edge of a countertop, whether it is drawn left to right, right to left, top to bottom, or bottom to top. The Default Depth can be changed under Settings. At this time, butterfly seams are not possible. In Step 5 Click on Area & Slab Layout. Click on the countertop and select Define Seams. Click inside the countertop at the approximate position of the seam. Click Save. Arrange the cut pieces on the Slab, click on any piece once for the submenu to rotate.

articles.title: Draw A Keyhole Peninsula
articles.content: Draw A Keyhole Peninsula Need to create a keyhole peninsula? Combine a rectangular top with Bump-Out Arcs and a Full Radius for the main shape. You will likely need to tinker with the measurements until you get the shape right. Draw a rectangle the go to Step 2 and click on one of the long edges and select Bump Out Arc. Select a Depth and Width and choose left or right, depending on which side of the counter should have the circular portion. Click on the opposite long edge and create another Bump Out Arc with the same Depth, Width, and opposite position. Click on the short end and choose Full Radius and enter the Depth.

articles.title: Draw Inside Diagonal Corner
articles.content: Draw Inside Diagonal Corner Draw your counter in Step 1. Go to Step 2 and click on an internal corner. Select Diagonal. Enter measure and Save.

articles.title: Slab Layout Colors
articles.content: Slab Layout Colors You may be wondering what all those colors mean when you look at your Slab Layout. When you layout your slab pieces in Step 5, you may see a variety of different colors. Each of these is telling you something about the way the piece fits on the slab. The most important thing is to remember that green means you are good to go! When the pieces turn green that means they are placed on the slab and not touching or overlapping. When you first open your Slab Layout, all the pieces will be stacked on top of each other and slightly off the slab. The color warnings prevent smaller pieces from accidentally getting lost under larger pieces.

articles.title: Quote Special Order Colors
articles.content: Quote Special Order Colors Need to quote Colors not listed in a Price List? This is useful for quoting Material Colors not normally stocked or ones being special ordered for a customer. Want to see the price per slab vs. the price by the square foot on the fly? Use the Other Color feature to quickly compare the two pricing methods. NOTE: If you do not see the Other Color option in Step 5, you will need to Edit your Price List to Allow Other Colors. In Step 5, select your material from the Product list. When selecting your Color, scroll to the very bottom of the list and select Other Color. Enter the Color Name and Price, and decide if you want it Priced By The Slab or to Allow Discount in Step 6. If you need to adjust the Price, do so in Step 5 for Other Colors. Click the Edit button next to the name of the Other Color.

articles.title: Draw Horizontal Seams
articles.content: Draw Horizontal Seams Need to run a seam down the long axis of a counter top? By default, seams are perpendicular to the Default Counter Depth edge of a countertop, whether it is drawn left to right, right to left, top to bottom, or bottom to top. Seams can be displayed vertically or horizontally, but can not be mixed in the same countertop. If you want the counter to appear horizontal in your customer drawing, rotate it in Step 1 after entering the dimensions. In Step 1 draw a counter with the length of the final piece. Click on the longest edge and enter the smaller dimension (usually 25.5) of the countertop. Click Save & Next and enter the larger dimension so that the piece is taller than it is wide, then Save. In Step 5 and click on Area & Slab Layout. Click once on the counter and select Define Seams from the pop-up menu. The seam is now horizontal rather than vertical.

articles.title: Draw Slide-In Range
articles.content: Draw Slide-In Range Need to add a space for an appliance? Create an opening for a slide-in range using a bump-in during Step 2. CounterGo will include the area of the bump-in when calculating square footage. Go to Step 2 and click on the countertop edge where you want to add cutout for a slide in range. Select Add Bump-In. Enter Depth and Width. Choose where you want the range to be positioned: you can make it Centered or specify how many inches from the Right or Left, then Save.

articles.title: Draw Vanity Extending Over Toilet
articles.content: Draw Vanity Extending Over Toilet Use the Notch feature in Step 2 to create a vanity that extends over a toilet or other structure. On Step 1 draw your countertop. Include the length of the extended piece in your total length. Go to Step 2 and click on the corner where the toilet is located. Select Notch. Enter the Length and Depth. Save. Note that the square feel calculated for material and/or fabrication will be the entire bounding rectangle - as if the notch piece had not been removed.

articles.title: Change Default Rounding
articles.content: Change Default Rounding Want to change the Default Rounding for all Quotes? Change the Default Rounding under Settings. You can still change the Default Rounding on any individual Quote or Order. Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Measurement and click Edit Measurement Settings. Select an option from the Default Rounding drop-down list then Save.

articles.title: Draw A Triangle
articles.content: Draw A Triangle CounterGo is intended to draw rectangular shapes that can be modified. It is possible to make very limited triangular shapes. Currently, you can only create right, isosceles triangles in CounterGo. You can experiment with the size of the clip to make it look right, or you can use Pythagorean Theorem to get the right length for the triangle you want to make. The square footage is determined by the original square or rectangle, indicated by the grey measurement arrows. In Step 1 Counter Dimensions, draw a square. Go to Step 2 Curves & Bumpouts. Click on one of the corners and select Clip. The result is a triangle.

articles.title: How Waterfalls & Mitered Cuts Are Calculated
articles.content: How Waterfalls & Mitered Cuts Are Calculated Are you wondering how Waterfall and Mitered Edges prices are calculated when adding them in Step 3? And how to enter your prices in the Price List? Prices for Mitered Cuts and Waterfall Installation can be added to the Price List, or manually entered in Step 6. Waterfall Material pricing is calculated based on the price of the Material selected in Step 5. Material pieces will be created and shown in Area & Slab Layout in Step 5. The total Linear Feet of the Mitered Cuts in Step 6 includes the edge between adjacent Mitered Cuts and Waterfalls. If you only charge for one cut, enter half the amount for Mitered Cuts in the Price List. For example, if you charge $40 per linear foot for only one cut, enter $20 for Mitered cuts in the Price List. If you charge for both cuts, then enter the full price, $40 in this example, for Mitered Cuts in the Price List. The Mitered Edge feature adds up the linear feet for the Mitered Cuts on all pieces and the shortest edge of any adjacent pieces. When a CounterGo Order is converted to a Systemize Job, the imported Order Information includes the total Material needed for the countertop, and the Mitered Cuts total.

articles.title: Add Or Remove Page Breaks In CounterGo Drawings
articles.content: Add Or Remove Page Breaks In CounterGo Drawings Do you have a Quote with a large number of countertops? Adding Page Breaks to the Drawing allows for counters to be grouped and viewed more clearly when printing or emailing. Countertops do not need to span the width of the drawing area, CounterGo will size them to fit the available space. Page Breaks can be added to the Drawing at any time during Steps 1-4. Page Breaks only break the Drawing area, they do not break any other areas on the Quote & Order Form. We recommend when printing or emailing, use a Form that has the Drawing area spanning the entire width of the page. Try using the default Forms, Quote W/Large Drawing. If you've deleted it, or need help creating a new Form, email our friendly CounterGo experts at support@moraware.com. ADD A DRAWING PAGE BREAK From the right side navigations, click the Page Break button > move your cursor up or down in the Drawing space > click to place the Page Break. Click and hold any Page Break to reposition it. REMOVE A DRAWING PAGE BREAK On the Quote Details page, click the Edit Drawing icon to open the Drawing. Click once on a Page Break > select Delete Page Break.

articles.title: Add Text To A Quote
articles.content: Add Text To A Quote Want to add custom text to your Quote & Order Forms for printing and emailing? You can't change the wording for the line items like Total, but you can add a text field to clarify any details, like adding that the total price includes tax. Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Forms > click the name of the Form you want to edit. Click on the Add icon across from Fields. Choose Static Text as the Data Type. Enter your message into the Text field then Save. The new Field will appear at the top of the Form. Drag and drop the field to the desired location.

articles.title: Apply Tax On A Quote Or Order
articles.content: Apply Tax On A Quote Or Order Ready to add tax to your Quote or Order? Tax Rates can be created and applied in Step 6 of a Quote or Order. Taxable Items will be marked with a "T" in Step 6 only. When printing or emailing, the total Tax amount will be listed above the Total Price. We can show you where to enter the taxes you have to collect in our software, but we can't advise you on what gets taxed, how much, or even which tax to charge, consult your Accountant or other tax professional. Go to Step 6 of your Quote or Order. Click the Edit Price Settings icon. Select <New Tax Rate> from the Tax Rate dropdown menu. Enter the Name and Tax percentage.

articles.title: Create Quote & Order Fields
articles.content: Create Quote & Order Fields Do you need to keep track of additional information in your Quotes and Orders? You can create a Field in the Info area of a Quote or Order to capture things like how the customer heard about your company or add an ID number. Once a Field is made, it can be added to any View. Or create a custom View of your Quotes and Orders that filters by the new Field. Go to Settings > Quote > Fields > Create. Enter a field Name. Choose a Data Type. For this example select List of Values. Enter the values that you want to appear in the drop-down list for this Field then Save. Open a Quote or Order and click the Edit Info icon. Choose from the List of Values for the Field.

articles.title: Change Default Quote Expiration
articles.content: Change Default Quote Expiration By default, your Quotes will remain active for 30 days. You can change the default Expiration date for all new Quotes you make by editing your Price List. You will need to make this change in each Price List you use. Go to Price Lists > click on the Name of the Price List to update > click the Edit Price List button. Click Settings from the left side menu. Enter the number of days before a Quote expires in the Expiration Days field. Save the Price List.

articles.title: How Square Footage Is Calculated
articles.content: How Square Footage Is Calculated Not sure if you should draw an L-shape or use a Bump-out? How a countertop is drawn can impact how square footage is calculated. There are several different ways the same shapes can be created. Most of the time, the simplest way to draw a counter is best. What goes on behind the scenes in CounterGo is fairly complex, so the most direct way to describe how square footage is calculated is to say that shapes are approximated and totaled. The gray arrows may seem to be indicating the area being calculated, but they represent the length of the edge of the original shape drawn, which is not always the same as the dimensions of the final shape after angles, curves, clips, bump-outs, or bump-ins are applied. Pricing by the Slab is a good way to make sure you don't under bid. And using the Slab Layout feature in Step 5 allows you to visualize what will fit on each slab. The example below will show you an L-shaped counter drawn two ways, as a continuous shape or as a Bump-out. More complex shapes have their area calculated by approximating the shape with smaller shapes and overlaps. CounterGo will always default to rounding that total up, not down, so you will not underestimate when Quoting. The counter on the left was drawn as an L-shape in Step 1. The counter on the right was drawn as a rectangle in Step 1, then a Bump-out was added during Step 2. The grey arrows showing the edge measurements vary between the two. On the counter on the left, the square footage calculated by the rectangles inside the L-shape, shown in red. On the right side counter, the area is calculated by the larger blue box that surrounds the entire counter. The square feet calculated for the Material, Fabrication & Installation charges are different in Step 6. There is also a line item for the Bump-out for the counter on the right.

articles.title: Digital Signatures
articles.content: Digital Signatures CounterGo does not currently have built-in support for capturing electronic signatures, but some fabricators capture signatures using a 3rd party app for PDF viewers. You can then attach the signature image file to the Quote. SOME APPS MORAWARE CUSTOMERS HAVE USED: SignEasy (for iPad) -- search for "SignEasy" in the app store, install it, test it, and make an account.Once SignEasy is installed, go back to CounterGo and print a Quote on your iPad (which creates a pdf). You'll see an option at the top of the screen to "Open in SignEasy" (sometimes you have to tap near the top of the screen to make that option reappear). From there, it's easy to have the customer sign it (probably want to use "2nd party" and/or "3rd party" signatures so that they're not saved) and mail YOU a copy. Once that's done, you'll see an email icon that you can tap again to mail the customer a copy. DocuSign MORAWARE PARTNER Job Well Done integrates tightly with JobTracker and Systemize and is focused on helping your field people (templaters and installers). It does a lot more than capture signatures, but capturing signatures is built in.

articles.title: Import Quote Forms
articles.content: Import Quote Forms In addition to creating printable Quote Forms manually, they can be exported and imported into CounterGo. The import instructions assume you have downloaded a valid printable Form in XML format. Go to Settings > Quote > Forms. Click +Create button at the top of the page. Click the Import icon. Click Choose File To Upload button and locate the XML form file. Click the Import button to complete import.

articles.title: Add Commission
articles.content: Add Commission There's not a built-in commission field in CounterGo, but you can create an Other Item to function like one. For variable or percentage commissions, the amount must be calculated outside of CounterGo and typed into each Quote in Step 6. Enabling Always Include this Item on Quotes, Edit Price on Quote, and leaving the Price at No price is a great way to help remind your salespeople to enter their variable or percentage commissions in Step 6. Go to Price Lists and click the Name of the Price List to modify. Click the Edit icon across from the Revision number. At the bottom of the Price List click the Add Other Item icon. Select appropriate options for the commission Other Item.

articles.title: Change Individual Slab Size
articles.content: Change Individual Slab Size Need to change Slab sizes for a particular Quote or Order? Planning to use a remnant? Slab sizes can be changed manually in Step 5 without changing the default size set in the Price List. Go to Step 5 > click Area # Slabs & Layout > check Show Layout. Click on the dimensions to the right of the layout. Enter the new dimensions and Save.

articles.title: Change The Account On A Quote
articles.content: Change The Account On A Quote Open the Quote and click the Edit icon. Click Move to Account button. Click the More button (3 dots) to see Accounts. Select an Account. Use the Search field if you don't see it right away. Click Save.

articles.title: Create An Account User
articles.content: Create An Account User Need to create a User that is only allowed to create, view, and edit Quotes & Orders for specific Accounts? CounterGo lets you create a unique kind of User called Account Users. This is most commonly used by fabricators who work with kitchen & bath dealers or by companies who dedicate salespeople to a particular Accounts. An Account User counts as a licensed CounterGo User. Adding an Account User will result in an additional monthly charge. Account Users are mostly defined by what they can NOT do. Security is intentionally limited with the rationale that Account Users are intended to be a dealer or salesperson responsible for generating Quotes or Orders for specific Accounts only, and not part of the everyday operations of a company. Account Users can: Create and edit Quotes & Orders. See a list of Quotes & Orders for their Accounts. Print Quotes & Orders to give to their prospects/customers. Account Users cannot: Send email directly from CounterGo. Edit prices. Add Miscellaneous Items. View or Edit the Price List. Copy Quotes or Orders. Delete Quotes or cancel Orders. See Account details. Change the salesperson. See a list of Accounts. Create Views - only the default view is available. CREATE AN ACCOUNT USER Login as a CounterGo Admin User and got to Settings > Users&Roles > Account Users. Click +Create to Create New User. Enter a User Name that is one word with no spaces, Password, Full Name, and Email Address for the new Account User.The Email Address entered is used to reset the password if the user forgets.Choose the Account(s) that you want this user to have access to when creating Quotes & Orders.If the Accounts do not yet exist, cancel this process and create the Account(s) first.

articles.title: Change Reply-To Email
articles.content: Change Reply-To Email Email Templates contain a Reply-To email address and From Name, along with the default text that will appear in the email Subject line and Body. Go to Settings > Quote > Email Templates. Click on the Email Template you want to edit. Enter a new Email address and Save. Note: You can have just one email template sent from "sales@mycompany.com" or you may choose to have a customized template for each salesperson sent from his or her own email address.

articles.title: Mark A Quote "Closed"
articles.content: Mark A Quote "Closed" CounterGo offers greater flexibility in handling Quote status through Custom Fields. With a Custom Field, it's possible to create a set of status choices such as Sold/Declined, Won/Lost, or Open/Closed. Once a Custom Field is defined for the Quote status, a View can be created displaying Quotes of a certain status. An example is a View of all Quotes marked as "Closed". The result of the View can be exported to Excel for additional reporting, analysis, and charting. CREATE A CUSTOM FIELD Go to Settings > Quote > Fields > +Create button to create a new Custom Field. Enter Name and select List of Values for Data Type. Enter "Open" and "Closed" in the List of Values field, one per line. Check "Searchable". The new field will now appear in the Quote Info area of every Quote. USE A CUSTOM FIELD To mark a Quote as open or closed, go to Quotes > Open a quote > Click the Edit icon across from Quote Info. Select from the drop-down List of Values.

articles.title: Create Custom Fields In Accounts
articles.content: Create Custom Fields In Accounts Need to track special info like a Billing ID or Account Number? You can easily create an Account Field for that. There are many kinds of Fields you can create listed under Data Type. Auto-number will generate a number for you, the other types you can manually enter a date, currency, text or numbers. If you plan to use this Field for searching, only Auto-number and Text are searchable Data Types. Go to Settings > Account > Account Fields. Click +Create. Enter a Name for the Field then select a Data Type and Save. To enter information in the new Field, open an Account and click Edit Account Info.

articles.title: Quote Multiple Color Or Material Options
articles.content: Quote Multiple Color Or Material Options Do you want to show customers how the total will change with multiple options of Materials, Colors, and Edges when pricing by the square foot? Use the Color Options feature in Step 5. This feature works best when all the Material chosen is priced by the square foot, or if all Slabs are the same size if pricing by the Slab. Square foot Material can be compared Material priced by the Slab. If you have multiple Areas in a Quote or Order, you can make different selections in each Area. When comparing Colors with different Slab Sizes, prices are calculated from the size of the first Color, which is referred to as Option #1, even if other Slabs are a different size. Re-ordering the Color Options will change the pricing based on the Color in the first, left-most position. For more information on adding Color Options to Print or Email, see Related Articles below. Check prices carefully if using the Color Options feature when quoting Material by the Slab where the Slabs differ in size. Select the first Material, Color & Edge in Step 5 then click the Add Color Option icon. Select the another Material, Color & Edge. To show Color Options on the printed Quote or Order, click Print > Quote (color options). If that Form does not appear in the drop-down list, see Related Articles to add Color Options to a Form. The printed or emailed Quote or Order will show details for the first option, and for comparison, it will show the totals for the other selections in the Color Option Field.

articles.title: Add A Page Break On Quote & Order Forms
articles.content: Add A Page Break On Quote & Order Forms Go to Settings > Quote > Forms and choose the form you would like to edit. Press the + to the right of Fields and select Data Type: Page Break Click the field Page Break and drag to the spot you would like to specify as the end of page one.

articles.title: Change Individual Quote Expiration Date
articles.content: Change Individual Quote Expiration Date Do you need to extend the Expiration Date of Quote? By default, Quotes will remain active for 30 days. Change the Expiration Date for an individual in the Price Settings area in Step 6. This will update the Expiration Date for that Quote only, not for any other Quote. Open the Drawing of a Quote > Go to Step 6. Click on the Edit icon across from Price Settings. Click the Calendar icon to select a new expiration date, then Save.

articles.title: Quote Materials Of Different Thickness Or Finish
articles.content: Quote Materials Of Different Thickness Or Finish Do you sell the same Product in different thicknesses or finishes? You can set up your CounterGo Price List to be able to quote the same Built-In Products with different thicknesses or finishes. The steps below to show how to add Cambria 2CM and Cambria 3CM to a Price List. Use the same steps to create Cambria Polished and Cambria Leathered. By renaming the Material you can add it again. Note: This will pull in all the built in Colors for that Material, but will not copy any prices or Color modifications already entered in the original. Go to Price List > Click on the name of the Price List to Edit > Click the Edit Price List button. Click Materials > Select a Material to modify from the submenu. Type in a new name. CounterGo will update the submenu immediately. Click on Add Material, and select the original Material to add. Modify the slab size or Colors. Rename the newly added Material. Save the Price List.If you need to occasionally add a variation, like a 2CM Product with a Leathered finish instead of standard, chose Other Color after selecting Cambria 2CM as the Product in Step 5 and specify the finish.

articles.title: View User Audit Log
articles.content: View User Audit Log It is sometimes useful to review the changes made by a specific CounterGo User. You can view the Change Log for a specific User, Quote or Account. Go to Settings > Users & Roles > Users and click on a User. Click the View Change Log button. You can scroll down through the changes or use the Find function in your browser to look for the name of a Quote or some other detail. Click the Options button if you want to broaden or narrow your Search. Select the number days and/or the action you're searching for. Click Apply. Notice the Search results are now much more focused.

articles.title: Payment Terms
articles.content: Payment Terms Payment Terms let you set expected payments from customers when you create a Quote. Payment Terms can be entered manually or assigned to a Price List or Account to automatically apply those terms when creating a Quote. The optional Terms field is for payment policies like Net 10, Net 30 or Due on Receipt and can be pulled into Quote & Order Forms. Deposits can be established as a percentage or a fixed amount and are shown in Quote & Order Lines. MANUALLY ENTER PAYMENT TERMS Create or open a Quote. Click the Edit Quote Info icon. Click the Edit Payment Terms icon. Enter the necessary Payment Terms for this Quote. After you Save, note that the Payment Terms are listed in the Quote Info Area and in the Quote Summary.

articles.title: Edit Fonts In Quote & Order Forms
articles.content: Edit Fonts In Quote & Order Forms Want to change the font, size or color in Quote & Order Forms? You can change font attributes for the entire Form, or for individual Fields. CHANGE ENTIRE FORM FONT ATTRIBUTES Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Forms and click the form you would like to edit. Click the Edit icon to the right of Form Template Info Click on the Label button to change the font for the Field Name. Click on the Value button to change the font of the body in the Field. Make your selections and then click Save. CHANGE INDIVIDUAL FIELD FONT ATTRIBUTES Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Forms and click the Form you would like to edit. Click in the Field to change. Click on the Label button to change the font for the Field Name. Click on the Value button to change the font of the body in the Field. Make your selections and then click Save.

articles.title: Revision Notes & Quote Notes
articles.content: Revision Notes & Quote Notes A little confused between Revision Notes and Quote/Order Notes? One shows when you view Revisions, and the other is in the Quote/Order Info area when viewing the details of the Quote or Order. Quote/Order Notes can be included in Forms for printing and emailing. REVISION NOTES When you Save a Quote or Order, you have the option to add notes about that Revision. These notes will appear when you view the list of Quote Revisions. When you click on See All next to the Revision number in a Quote or Order Detail view, you'll see any notes you've entered. QUOTE & ORDER NOTES When viewing a Quote or Order, click the Edit icon in the Quote/Order Info area to add notes.

articles.title: Quote Commercial Jobs
articles.content: Quote Commercial Jobs Though CounterGo is not designed for commercial jobs, they can be quoted. If you send your CounterGo Orders to Systemize, or export your Orders to Quickbooks, we suggest scheduling a support call to talk over your process before following the directions below. Email us at support@moraware.com to set up a time to talk. When estimating commercial work, there are three steps to keep in mind: This method relies on pricing by the square foot, so calculate your square foot pricing. Draw and calculate the price for one counter or counter set. Adjust for tax. Pricing commercial jobs correctly is more complicated than pricing a residential job - so do your own due diligence before using this technique. Feel free to ask us for help if you have questions. CALCULATE PRICE AND ZERO WASTEWhen using this method to calculate commercial jobs, it is necessary to calculate pricing by the square foot, even if you normally price by the slab. Calculate the price you want to charge per square foot for your job. If you normally charge by the slab. The spreadsheet below can help you determine the square foot price for the commercial job. Calculate-zero-waste-sq-ft-price.xlsx Calculate-zero-waste-meter-price.xlsx CREATE THE QUOTEBasically, we will create and price a single room, then multiply by the number of rooms that will be in the job. Create a new Quote and draw the counter shapes in Step 1. For this example, let's make two counters with a simple splash and a sink. Proceed through the Steps 1-5 as you would for a regular quote. In Step 5, select Material, Color, and Edge.. Move to Step 6 and apply a tax rate as you normally would. In this example, only the physical items are taxed, your tax rules may be slightly different. Now you have the cost of one room including tax. Before adding an Other Item to multiply by the remaining rooms, tax needs to be added as a line item, then removed from the overall quote, otherwise, the tax would be applied incorrectly. Add an Other Item in the area for Single Apartment called "Sales Tax on Goods". Make sure the Other Item is NOT taxable. Edit your Price Settings to remove Tax Rate from the Quote. Now it's time to add an Other Item for the remaining rooms of the job called "Additional Apartments 2-20". Use the Subtotal price from Single Apartment and enter the remaining number of rooms. This practice quote is for an apartment complex with 80 rooms, so 79 additional rooms are needed. Make sure the Other Item is NOT taxable. MULTIPLE LAYOUTS WITH MULTIPLE ROOMSEven if you have more than one layout type, and multiple rooms per that layout, use the same approach. Create all layouts in Step 1. Assign each Layout its own Area in Step 5. Use the same approach as above to calculate the cost per area, adding a line item for tax for each area.

articles.title: Organize Color Options
articles.content: Organize Color Options Do you need to change the order of Color Options? When quoting multiple Colors using Color Options, the Slab Layout, details, and prices are shown are calculated from Color Option #1 only. The Color Options can be re-ordered to switch Color Option #1 and what is displayed on Quotes. When comparing Colors with different Slab Sizes, prices are calculated from the size of the first Color, which is referred to as Color Option #1, even if other Slabs are a different size. A warning will appear if different Slab Sizes have been selected. Go to Step 5 > click the Re-Order Color Options icon. Click, hold, and drag an Option to re-order > Save. When the Quote is printed or emailed, the Color Option #1 will be listed in the Quote Lines. The totals for each of the Color Options will appear in the Color Options Field.

articles.title: Revert To Previous Quote Or Order Revision
articles.content: Revert To Previous Quote Or Order Revision Need an earlier version of a Quote or Order? Each time a Quote is saved, a new Revision is created. There may be times when you find it necessary to revert the Quote back to an earlier version. To switch a Quote back to a previous Revision, you will need to select the Revision within the Drawing steps. Revisions can not be deleted, so you will always have a record of changes made to Quotes and Orders. Open the Quote by clicking the Edit icon to re-open the Quote Drawing. Click the Revisions icon from the top menu bar. Choose the Revision you want and click Revert to Revision then Save the Quote.

articles.title: Import Account Info
articles.content: Import Account Info Most fabricators simply enter their Accounts manually, as they create new Quotes. Others find it useful to have one person on their team enter the Account contact information so they can update records as they go. If you have up-to-date Account information stored in another database and can export that data to a spreadsheet, we can also import it into CounterGo for you. Some common fields we can import include: Account Name Salesperson Account Notes Contact Name Address Phone number Email If you have special fields that you want to import, create your Account Custom Fields first. When you're ready, email your spreadsheet to support@moraware.com!

articles.title: Move A Standalone Quote Or Order To An Existing Account
articles.content: Move A Standalone Quote Or Order To An Existing Account Need to move a Quote from Standalone into an Account? It's easy to move Quotes and Orders to existing Accounts. If you also use Systemize, a Standalone Quote or Order must be in an Account before it can create a Job directly from the Quote or Order. Open the Quote or Order and click Edit icon in the Quote or Order Info area. Click Move to Account icon. If you know the Account name, you can type it into the box to select. Or, click the More icon to see a list of all your Accounts. Select the Account and cick Save then Save again.

articles.title: Add Extra Items To A Quote
articles.content: Add Extra Items To A Quote Do you have charges like faucets, tear-out, or travel that you need to charge for on a Quote or Order? You can add a charge for items or services that are not captured in the drawing as Other Items when you are in Step 6. Adding an Other Item in Step 6 only adds it to that particular Quote or Order, not to to the Price List. in Step 6, click the Add icon in the Area where you want to add the item or service. Select Add Miscellaneous Item then enter the details for the item. If you want the Other Item to appear in its own Area, select Area: Other Items when adding the Other Item. Entering a negative number in the Price field when adding an Other Item will result in a credit.

articles.title: Add A Quote Number To Each Quote
articles.content: Add A Quote Number To Each Quote Want to automatically add a unique Quote Number to every Quote? Create an Auto-numbered Field in CounterGo to assign a number to each Quote as it's created. You can also add custom prefixes and suffixes to the numbers. Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Fields. Click the Create button. Name your Field and choose Auto-number as the Data Type.If you want this number added to all of your existing Quotes, check Generate value for all existing CGQuotes at the bottom. The new Field will appear in the Quote Info and Order Info areas in a Quote or Order. Add this Field into Quote & Order Forms to have it displayed on printed and emailed Quotes & Orders.

articles.title: Show Or Hide Measurements Or Slab Counts
articles.content: Show Or Hide Measurements Or Slab Counts Quote Forms are customizable. Line Drawings can be shown without Measurements, Seams or Slab Images. To show any of these in a printed or emailed Quote again, check these same boxes to include them in the Quote Form. In the line items area, you can also select to omit the total square footage & Slab Count. HIDE MEASUREMENTS ON DRAWING Go to Settings > Quote > Forms > click on the Form to edit > click on the Field with the thumbnail drawing. Uncheck "Include Measurements". REMOVE TOTAL SQUARE FOOTAGE AND SLAB COUNT Go to Settings > Quote > Forms > click on the Form to edit > click on the field with the example line items listed. Uncheck "Include Measurements" to remove the total square footage listed before the product. Uncheck "Include Slab Count" to remove the slab count from the printed quote.

articles.title: Duplicate A Quote
articles.content: Duplicate A Quote Need to quickly make a Quote that is similar to an existing one? Duplicate the Quote then make any necessary changes. Open a Quote and click the Edit Quote Info icon. Click the Duplicate Quote icon. Enter a Quote Name and select which items you want included in the new Quote. No results found

articles.title: Add Salespeople
articles.content: Add Salespeople Need to assign a Salesperson to a Quote or Order? Add Salespeople under Settings. Go to Settings > Account > Salespeople. Click the Create button at the top. Type the name of each Salesperson, one per line.

articles.title: Delete A Quote
articles.content: Delete A Quote Do you need to delete CounterGo Quote instead of letting it expire? Once you delete a quote from the system it is gone. There is no "undo" key. Select the Quote you would like to delete. Click the Edit icon above the Quote Info box. At the top of the Edit Quote Info click the Delete icon.

articles.title: Disable Or Delete An Account User
articles.content: Disable Or Delete An Account User No longer need an Account User? You can disable or delete an Account User. What's the difference between disabling and deleting? By disabling the Account User you maintain a record of everything the user worked on. They will no longer have access to login, and you will no longer be charged for that user. We recommend disabling an Account User over deleting. Disabling the Account User is also useful if the person is taking a temporary or seasonal leave. A disabled Account User can be restored by a CounterGo Admin User at any time. If an Account User is deleted and it is needed again, a new Account User must be created. DISABLE AN ACCOUNT USER Go to Settings > Users & Roles > Account Users and click on the name of the user. Check Disabled to suspend the Account. You will not be billed for Account Users that are Disabled. DELETE AN ACCOUNT USER Go to Settings > Users & Roles > Account Users and click on the name of the user. Click the Delete icon at the top of the Edit User box then confirm.

articles.title: Add Text Line Items To A Quote
articles.content: Add Text Line Items To A Quote Do you need to add some additional information to a Quote under the Line Items? Add Text Items using the Other Items Menu is Step 6. There is a 1000 character limit when adding Text Items. Text Items can be hidden on Quotes so they are not visible when printed or emailed, and re-ordered among added miscellaneous Other Items. Added Text Items can not be re-ordered within Price Line items. In Step 6, click the Add Other Items icon next to any Area. Select Add Text Item. Enter the text, select the Area to place the text > Save.

articles.title: Re-Order Text Items In A Quote
articles.content: Re-Order Text Items In A Quote Have you added Text Items to a Quote? Text Items and Miscellaneous Items that are a one time add on, can be re-ordered among those items. they can not be moved up or down within items from the Price List. Text Items can not be added to the Price List. In Step 6, click on any added Text Item. Click the Re-Order Lines icon in the top menu bar. Click, hold, and drag line items into the desired order. Click the Re-Order button > Save.

articles.title: Add Counter Material Without A Drawing To A Quote With Drawings
articles.content: Add Counter Material Without A Drawing To A Quote With Drawings Do you want to add a counter without a drawing to a Quote that already has drawings? Counters without a drawing can be added to a Quote that has a drawing at any time. Drawn counters can be added to Quotes without drawings too. It is not possible to automatically convert one to the other. Counters without a drawing can be added or edited at any point during Steps 1-4. ADD COUNTERS WITHOUT A DRAWING Create or open a Quote with a countertop drawing. Go to Step 1 > click the Add Other Counter button. Name the Counter and select to enter the size either the square footage or the counter measurements. Add a Splash, enter the height and the size either by inches or linear feet. Enter an Edge length by either inches or linear feet. Add Curves & Bumpouts, additional Splash & Edges, or Sinks & Cutouts using the buttons across the bottom. EDIT COUNTERS WITHOUT A DRAWING In Step 1, Material without a drawing is listed under the Add Other Counter button on the right side. Click on the counter Name to edit.

articles.title: Add Or Delete Curves & Bumpouts To A Counter Without A Drawing
articles.content: Add Or Delete Curves & Bumpouts To A Counter Without A Drawing Are you ready to add Curves and BumpOuts to a Quote without drawings? Curves & BumpOut information for Quotes without drawings can be added when entering information for the counter. Counters without a drawing can be added or edited at any point during Steps 1-4. ADD CURVES & BUMPOUTS Go to Step 1 > click the Add Other Counter button> Enter countertop information. Click the Curves & Bumpouts button > select an option from the menu. Enter details needed for the selection. REMOVE CURVES & BUMPOUTS Go to Step 1 > Click on the Name of the countertop without a drawing. Click the Delete icon across from the Curve or Bumpout to remove.

articles.title: Quote Counters Without A Drawing
articles.content: Quote Counters Without A Drawing Do you want to create a Quote without a drawing of the counter? CounterGo allows counters to be quoted without creating a drawing. Splash and Edge are required Fields, if they are not needed, they can be deleted. Counters without a drawing can be added or edited at any point during Steps 1-4. Click on Quotes from the left side navigation > click the Create icon at the top. Enter a Quote Name. Select an Account or set as Standalone. In Step 1, click Add Other Counter from the right navigation. Name the Counter and select to enter the size either the square footage or the counter measurements. Add a Splash, enter the height and the size either by inches or linear feet. Enter an Edge length by either inches or linear feet. Add Curves & Bumpouts, additional Splash & Edges, or Sinks and Cutouts using the buttons across the bottom. EDIT A QUOTE WITHOUT A DRAWING In Step 1, Material without a drawing is listed under the Add Other Counter button on the right side. Click on the counter Name to edit.

articles.title: Add Or Delete Sinks & Cutouts To A Counter Without A Drawing
articles.content: Add Or Delete Sinks & Cutouts To A Counter Without A Drawing Do you need to add or remove Sinks or Cutouts to a counter without drawings? Sink and Cutout information for Quotes without drawings can be added when entering information for the counter. Counters without a drawing can be added or edited at any point during Steps 1-4. ADD SINKS & CUTOUTS Go to Step 1 > click the Add Other Counter button> Enter countertop information. Click the Sinks & Cutouts button > select an option from the menu. Enter details needed for the selection. REMOVE SINKS & CUTOUTS Go to Step 1 > Click on the Name of the countertop without a drawing. Click the Delete icon across from the Sink or Cutout to remove.

articles.title: Add Or Delete Splash & Edge To A Counter Without A Drawing
articles.content: Add Or Delete Splash & Edge To A Counter Without A Drawing Do you need to add an additional Splash and/or Edge to a Quote without drawings? When creating a Quote without a drawing, Splash and Edge are automatically included as default Fields. If they are not needed, they can be deleted with the Delete icon adjacent to the Field. If additional Splash and/or Edges are needed, or if they were previously deleted, add by using the Splash & Edge button. Counters without a drawing can be added or edited at any point during Steps 1-4. ADD SPLASH & EDGE Go to Step 1 >click the Add Other Counter button > Enter countertop information. Click the Splash & Edge button > select an option from the menu. Enter details needed for the selection. REMOVE SPLASH & EDGE Go to Step 1 > Click on the Name of the countertop without a drawing. Click the Delete icon across from the Splash or Edge to remove.

articles.title: Quote Statuses & How They Change
articles.content: Quote Statuses & How They Change Not sure about what a particular Quote Status means, or how to change it? CounterGo Quotes have three Statuses; Draft, Active, and Expired. Draft: a Quote that has been created but no Drawing or Other Counter has been added and/or Saved. Active: a Quote that is not a Draft or Expired. An Active Quote can change Status to Expired if it is older than the Default Quote Expiration, it can not turn back into a Draft. Expired: A Quote that is older than the Default Quote Expiration. Expired Quotes can be updated and made Active again. CHANGE A DRAFT TO ACTIVE Open the Quote > Click the Edit icon. Even if you do not add a countertop or countertop Drawing, click the Save button at the top right corner. CHANGE AN EXPIRED QUOTE TO ACTIVE Open the Quote > Click the Edit icon. In the top message banner, click on Update Expiration Date. Select a new Expiration Date > Save > Save the Quote.

articles.title: Quote Multiple Quantities
articles.content: Quote Multiple Quantities Do you have multiples of the same layout in a Quote? Multiply an Area in Step 6 to quickly estimate the total price for multiple units with the same layout. Each Area can be multiplied individually. Every Line Item, except for Text Lines, will be multiplied for that Area. When using the Quantity feature, square footage is rounded up using the same method as a standard Quote. If there are some items that only need to be calculated once, put them in a separate Area and leave the Quantity as 1. Add a Text Line Item before multiplying to see a per unit amount if needed. There will only be one Layout in Step 5 to arrange on Slabs. The total number of estimated Slabs will be calculate, and show in Step 6, but only one Layout is available in Step 5. ADJUST AREA QUANTITY Draw a countertop(s) > Select all necessary options in Steps 1-5. Go to Step 6 click the Edit icon next to an Area. Enter the Quantity for the Area > Save. CREATE A PER UNIT TEXT LINE Draw a countertop(s) > Select all necessary options in Steps 1-5. Go to Step 6 > click the Add Other Item icon. Select Text Item > enter the Subtotal for the Area > Save. In Step 6 click the Edit icon next to an Area. Enter the Quantity for the layout in that Area > Save.

articles.title: Create A Field For Quote Account Type
articles.content: Create A Field For Quote Account Type Do you want to organize and track the types of Accounts when creating Quotes? Create a List Of Values Field, and that Field will be available to edit in the Quote Info Area. Go to Settings > Quote & Order > Fields. Click the Create button in the top menu bar > Name the Field > Select List Of Values for Data Type. Enter each Account type, one per line > Select any additional options > Save. Open any Quote > click the Edit Quote Info icon > Select an Account Type from the drop-down list for the new Field.

articles.title: Move Counters Without Drawings To Different Areas
articles.content: Move Counters Without Drawings To Different Areas Do you need to move or assign counters without drawings to different Areas in a Quote? Assign counters without drawings to Areas at any point in Steps 1-5, to any of the Areas created in Step 5. If no Areas appear when editing a counter without a drawing, go to Step 5 and create the Area(s), then edit the counter. Click on the Name of a counter without a drawing. Select an Area from the drop-down list of available areas > Done.

articles.title: Revise A Quote
articles.content: Revise A Quote Do you need other make revisions to an existing Quote? There are several areas that can be updated if a Quote needs changes after it's been created. Even Expired Quotes can be updated. EDIT QUOTE INFO & QUOTE ADDRESS From any Quote View, click on a Quote Name to open. Edit any information in the Quote Info area by clicking on the Edit Quote Info icon. Edit Quote Address information by clicking on the Edit Address icon. EDIT QUOTE DRAWING From any Quote View, click on a Quote Name to open. Click the Edit Quote Drawing in the upper right corner, above the Quote Summary. If this is an older Quote, and has expired, a message to update the Quote Expiration Date will appear. Click Update Expiration Date > select a new Expiration Date > Save. If this Quote used an earlier version of the Price List, a message will be displayed. Updating the Quote to the current Price List will update the Quote to current prices, not what was originally quoted. Keep original prices by dismissing the message.
